Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Visiglow: A High-throughput Vision Assessment Tool
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to completely transform vision screening. With this technology pharmaceutical companies can automatically and rapidly screen thousands of compounds with non-technically trained staff in multiple animal models. The long-term beneficial consequences of the proposed work will include: 1) expanding the breath of translational research because the technology can be used in all seeing verbal and nonverbal animals (i.e., drosophila, zebrafish, mice, rabbits, human adults and infants); 2) accelerate compound screening, and 3) ultimately, reduce the cost and time from drug discovery to market.

This I-Corps project advances vision screening. The technology is analogous to a customizable disco ball, that can automatically alter light displays to non-invasively assess multiple aspects of vision in seeing verbal and nonverbal animals. Our past research has proven the technology is well-matched to screen multiple aspects of vision within 20s in zebrafish, an important biomedical model. It is a platform technology, therefore the invention will be important for high throughput screening of pharmaceutical compounds, biological mutants, and toxicological agents in diverse biomedical models, thereby advancing drug discovery, gene therapies, and quality control and assurance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One grand challenge is how to feed the next 10 billion people expected on the planet by 2050. Natural food systems cannot meet this demand. The demand is predicted to be met by aquaculture. Our technology, Visioglow helps solve the food conversion ratio in aquaculture. Food conversion ratio is pain for farmers, because feed represents 40-70% of production costs. Hence, there is a need for our technology to help ensure food security for the next 10 billion people on the planet. 

The I-Corps project explores the commercialization potential of an emerging technology at the intersection of the Aquaculture and pharmaceutical application space.The intellectual merit of this project included developing and understanding the commercial opportunities of an automated, running wheel for fish that could be used for high-throughput screening of biomedical models or employed to exercise fish on farms.  

Significant results include identifying customer segments, the discovery of pivots necessary to target these segments, and pinpointing value propositions for these customer segments. The primary value proposition was the ability to reduce feed conversion rate in trout by 10% and reduce the time to market of the trout by one month for trout farmers, thereby enabling them to preserve their family legacy. 

The project has provided many opportunities for training and professional development, including attending the U.S. Trout Farmer?s Association and Idaho Aquaculture Association meetings, and entrepreneurship training materials. In addition, individual meetings were conducted with stakeholders in pharmaceuticals, environmental health and safety, trout farmers, catfish farmers, National Aquaculture Association members, software developers, and LED manufacturers. Companies and organizations that the team interviewed included Western Regional Aquaculture Center and Cooke Aquaculture Pacific, one of the largest aquaculture producers. 

The broader impacts of this work include: 1) dissemination of knowledge acquired during the NSF I-Corps program, and 2) increased potential for impact in pharmaceutical and aquaculture industries. The information acquired during the I-Corps project have been disseminated through presentations, pitch competition,  and conversations with other entrepreneurs to encourage participation in future cohorts. We conducted 242 customer discovery interviews during the project period. During the seven-week program, the team executed 127 customer discovery interviews with stakeholders in biomedical research, municipal environmental health and safety, fish and wildlife and aquaculture. After the program ended, the team performed an additional 115 interviews targeting the other areas of the business model canvas including Channels, Customer Relationships, and Key Activities. The team?s involvement led to talks to develop a technology to be piloted at Cooke Aquaculture or another member of the Western Regional Aquaculture Center. 

Through I-Corps, the team was able to identify problems in the trout aquaculture space that could benefit from animal behavior-informed technology. In particular, the team learned that a 10% improvement in the feed conversion ratio would significantly affect trout farmer?s bottom line, and enable them to stay in business so that they can preserve their family legacy. This discovery was made through in-person interviews and touring the facilities where farmers work.

Modified by: Delia S Shelton
